Off, blubb'ring Melancholy!</br>Of the blue Devils and Book-learning born,</br>In dusty schools forlorn,</br>Amongst black gowns, square caps, and books unjolly,</br>Hunt out some College cell,</br>Where muzzing quizzes utter monkish schemes—</br>And the old Proctor dreams:</br>There, in thy smutty walls, o'er-run with dock,</br>As ragged as thy smock,</br>With rusty, fusty fellows ever dwell.

But come, thou baggage fat and free,</br>By Gentles called Festivity,</br>And by us, Rolling-kiddies — Fun,</br>Whom Mother Shipton, one by one,</br>With two Wapping wenches more,</br>To skipping Harlequin bore,</br>Or whether, as some deeper say,</br>Jack Pudding, on a holiday,</br>Along with Jenny Diver romping,</br>As he met her once a pumping,</br>There, on heaps of dirt, and mortar—</br>And cinders wash'd in cabbage-water,</br>Fill'd her with thee — a strapping lassie,</br>So spunky, brazen, bold, and saucy.

Hip! — here, Jade!  and bring with thee</br>Jokes and snigg'ling jollity,</br>Christmas gambols, waggish tricks,</br>Winks, wry faces, licks, and kicks,</br>Such as fall from Moggy's knuckles,</br>And love to live about her buckles;</br>Spunk, that hobbling Watchmen boxes,</br>And Horse-laugh hugging both his Doxies;</br>Come, and kick it as you go—</br>On the stumping hornpipe toe;</br>And in thy right-hand haul with thee</br>The MOUNTAIN brim — French Liberty;</br>And, if I give thee puffing due,</br>Fun, admit me of thy crew—</br>To pig with her, and pig with thee,</br>In everlasting frolicks free;</br>To hear the Sweep begin his beat,</br>And, squalling, startle the dull street,</br>From his watchbox in the alley</br>'Till the Watch, at six, doth sally,</br>Then to go, in spite of sleep,</br>And at the window cry — "Sweep; sweep!"</br>Thro' the street-door, or the airy—</br>Or, in the Country, thro' the dairy;</br>While the Dustman, with his din,</br>Bawls and rings to be let in;</br>And, at the fore, or at the back-door,</br>Slowly plods his jades before,</br>Oft hearing the Sow-gelder's horn</br>Harshly rouse the snoring Morn,</br>From the side of some large square,</br>Thro' the long street grunting far.

Sometimes walking I'll be seen</br>By Tow'r-hill, or Moorfields green,</br>Right against old Bedlam-gate,</br>Where the mock King begins his state—</br>Crown'd with straw and rob'd with rags,</br>Cover'd o'er with jags and tags,</br>While the Keeper, near at hand,</br>Bullies those that leave their stand;</br>And Milkmaids' screams go thro' your ears,</br>And Grinders sharpen rusty sheers,</br>And ev'ry crier squalls his cry</br>Under each window he goes by.

Straight mine eye hath caught new gambols,</br>While round and round this town it rambles:</br>Sloppy streets and foggy day,</br>Where the bland'ring folks do stray;</br>Pavements, on whose greasy flags</br>Sweating Coachmen flog their nags;</br>Barbers jostled 'gainst your side,</br>Narrow streets and gutters wide.

Grub-street garrets now it sees,</br>To the Muse open — and the breeze;</br>Where, perhaps, some Scribbler hungers—</br>The hack of neighbouring newsmongers.</br>Hard by a Tinker's furnace smokes,</br>From betwixt two pastry-cooks,</br>Where Dingy Dick and Peggy, met,</br>Are at their scurvy dinner set—</br>Of cow-heel and such cellar messes,</br>Which the splay-footed Rachel dresses;</br>And then with haste her mate she leaves,</br>And, with the boy, the bellows heaves;</br>Or, if 'tis late, and shop be shut,</br>Scrubs, at the pump, her face from smut.

Sometimes, all for sights agog,</br>To t' other end of town I jog,</br>When St. James's bells ring round,</br>And the Royal fiddles sound;</br>When ev'ry Lord and Lady's bum</br>Jigs it in the Drawing-room,</br>And young and old dance down the tune,</br>In honour of — the fourth of June;</br>'Till candles fail, and eyes are sore—</br>Then hie we home to talk it o'er,</br>With stories told of many a treat—</br>How Lady Swab the sweetmeats eat!</br>She was pinch'd — and something worse,</br>And she was fobb'd, and lost her purse!</br>Tell how the drudging — sweat,</br>To bake his custards duly set,</br>When in one night, e'er clock went seven,</br>His 'Prentice-lad had robb'd the oven</br>Of more than twenty hands had put in,</br>Then lies him down — the little glutton!</br>Stretch'd slumb'ring 'fore the fire, they tell ye,</br>And bakes the custards in his belly;</br>Then, cropsick, down the stairs he flings—</br>Before his Master's bell yet rings.</br>Thus, done the tales, to bed they creep—</br>By hoofs and wheels soon lull'd asleep.

But the City takes me then,</br>And the hums of busy men,</br>Where throngs of trainband Captains bold,</br>In time of peace, fierce meetings hold,</br>With stores of Stock-jobbers, whose lies</br>Work change of Stocks and bankruptcies;</br>While Bulls and Bears alike contend</br>To get that cash they dare not spend.

Then let Aldermen appear,</br>In scarlet robe and chandelier,</br>And City feasts and gluttony,</br>With balls upon the Lord Mayor's day;</br>Sights that young 'prentices remember</br>Sleeping and waking all November.
Then to the Playhouses anon,</br>If Quick or Bannister be on,</br>Or drollest Parsons, child of Drury,</br>Bawls out his damns with comic fury.

And ever against hum-drum cares,</br>Sing me some of Dibdin's airs;</br>Married to his own queer wit,</br>Such as my shaking sides may split,</br>In notes, with many a jolly bout,</br>Near Beaufort's Buildings oft roar'd out,</br>With wagging curls and smirks so cunning,</br>His rig on many a booby running,</br>Exposing all the ways and phizzes</br>Of "Wags and Oddities and Quizzes;"</br>That Shuter's self might heave his head</br>From drunken snoozes, on a bed</br>Of pot-house benches sprawl'd, and hear,</br>Such laughing songs as won the ear</br>Of all the town, his slip to cover,</br>Whene'er he met 'em half seas over.
Freaks like these if thou canst give,</br>Fun with thee I wish to live.</br>
